topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0 Beta: Overview

section.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is a carrier grade OpenStack solution plus compute and network functions virtualization (NFV) offering that enables CSPs to deploy applications on open source software platforms. HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is based on OpenStack Kilo.

Some key examples include the host operating system (for example, Linux), server virtualization (KVM), network virtualization (vSwitch and SDN controllers), an installer and cloud lifecycle management framework, fault and performance management, and high-availability framework for the OpenStack control plane and the NFVI layer.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is based on HP Helion OpenStack 1.1 but with significantly enhanced and optimized functionality, availability, scale and performance to meet the needs of NFV cloud deployments.
Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes following key components:

ul.li: OpenStack—core services including Horizon, Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, Swift, Keystone, Ceilometer, and Heat. Other services will be added as needed in the future.

Compute node software package that includes:
Carrier-grade Linux (host operating system [OS] running on the compute nodes)
Carrier-grade KVM (for virtualization of the compute node)
Carrier-grade accelerated virtual switch (AVS), data plane development kit (DPDK)-enabled high-performance virtual switch
Management and middleware—composed of high-availability (HA) management; operations, administration, and maintenance (OAM); software image management; and fault and performance management
Guest software development kit (SDK) for inclusion in the guest OS of the VNF for performance acceleration and improving the HA framework above and beyond standard VIMs
HPE Helion Lifecycle Manager (HLM)—cloud installer and lifecycle manager
Near-line rate networking throughout for VNFs like vEPC, vBRAS, vIMS, vFW, vRouter etc.
Advanced resource scheduling and orchestration capabilities
NIC Bonding at the server level
Compute Node failure detection and Auto-evacuation in kvm region

Virtual Switching
Virtual switching is a key function within data centers based on Software Defined Networking (SDN) as well as in telecom infrastructure that leverages Network Functions Virtualization (NFV).
In the NFV scenario, for example, the virtual switch (vSwitch) is responsible for switching network traffic between the core network and the virtualized applications or Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) that are running in Virtual Machines (VMs). HPE DCN Virtual Routing Switch (VRS). HPE DCN VRS is..
Accelerated vSwitch (AVS). AVS is integrated into the servers in the KVM region. AVS is an optimization of Open vSwitch (OVS) technology for NFV environments. Open vSwitch is a multilayer software switch licensed under the open source Apache 2 license.

section.title: Ethernet Interface Types
section.p: You can connect a VM directly to a physical interface using PCI passthrough or SR-IOV. You can choose either method by selecting pci-sriov or pci-passthrough as the network type when creating interfaces.

When compared with a PCI Passthtrough Ethernet interface, a SR-IOV Ethernet interface:
Provides benefits similar to those of a PCI Passthtrough Ethernet interface, including lower latency packet processing.
Scales up more easily in a virtualized environment by providing multiple VFs that can be attached to multiple virtual machine interfaces.
Shares the same limitations, including the lack of support for LAG, QoS, ACL, and live migration.
Has the same requirements regarding the VLAN configuration of the access switches.
Provides a similar configuration workflow.
Refer to the KVM Region Administrator Guide for more information on PCI Pass-through and SR-IOV.

PCI Passthrough. A passthrough Ethernet interface is a physical PCI Ethernet NIC on a compute node to which a virtual machine is granted direct access. This minimizes packet processing delays but at the same time demands special operational considerations. For all purposes, a PCI passthrough interface behaves as if it were physically attached to the virtual machine.
Instructions for configuring SR-IOV are available after for installation, see Configuring PCI-Passthrough

SR-IOV. A Single-Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) Ethernet interface is a physical PCI Ethernet NIC that implements hardware-based virtualization mechanisms to expose multiple virtual network interfaces that can be used by one or more virtual machines simultaneously.

When compared with a PCI Passthtrough Ethernet interface, a SR-IOV Ethernet interface:
Provides benefits similar to those of a PCI Passthtrough Ethernet interface, including lower latency packet processing.
Scales up more easily in a virtualized environment by providing multiple VFs that can be attached to multiple virtual machine interfaces.
Shares the same limitations, including the lack of support for LAG, QoS, ACL, and live migration.
Has the same requirements regarding the VLAN configuration of the access switches.
Provides a similar configuration workflow when used on HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade.
Instructions for configuring SR-IOV are available after for installation, see Configuring SR-IOV.

section.title: Backup and Restore
section.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes a backup and restore application called Attis which you can use to backup and restore essential system files and components of the non-KVM cloud. Attis is automatically installed on each of the controller nodes in the non-KVM region. For more information, see Backup and Restore Configuration Files and MySQL Clusters.

section.title: Multiple NIC Support
section.p: When launching a VM instance, you can specify multiple network interfaces.

section.title: Centralized Logging
section.p: The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Centralized Logging feature collects logs on a central system, rather than leaving the logs scattered across the network. The administrator can use a single Kibana interface to view log information in charts, graphs, tables, histograms, and other forms. For more information, see Centralized Logging.

body.section:
Installation OptionsHP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade has two baremetal installation options depending on your system configuration. It allows you to manage the KVM and VMware ESX hypervisors and provision virtual machines.
You can find more information on the hypervisor options in the Technical Overview. KVM Topology
If you install the KVM deployment, you can integrate either HPE Storevirtual (VSA) or HP StoreServ (3PAR) storage in the KVM region.
With HPE StoreVirtual VSA storage
HPE StoreVirtual VSA software is a Virtual Storage Appliance that provides the complete array functionality on top of a Linux KVM environment without external hardware. VSA eliminates the need for external shared storage required to implement Block Storage features.
With HPE StoreServ (3PAR) storage
HPE 3PAR StoreServ is a storage array that supports Fibre Channel (FC) as well as iSCSI protocol.
You must install 3PAR or VSA before starting the HP Helion OpenStack installation and are independent of HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade. KVM with DCN Topology
The KVM topology can be optimized using HPE DCN Virtual Routing Switch.
Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) is a Software-Defined Networking (SDN) solution that provides data center (DC) network virtualization and automatically establishes connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.KVM + ESX TopologyThe ESXi/DCN integration enables data-center-to-data-center communications through DCN, which connects to the KVM region through a gateway (VRS-G).
HP Helion OpenStack supports VMWare ESX hypervisor. With our ESX integration, you can provision and manage an overcloud ESX cluster. VMWare vCenter Compute driver is used as a part of ESX integration. The VMware vCenter driver connects to ESX clusters in a vCenter through Compute proxy nodes.
Virtual networking between HP Helion Carrier Grade and the ESX servers is handled by HPE Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) is a software-defined networking (SDN) solution that enhances data center (DC) network virtualization by automatically establishing connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.
The ESX integration uses the OVSvApp application to connect the vCenter networking to the Network Operations controller to manage workload networks.
You can also integrate HPE Storevirtual (VSA) or HPE StoreServ (3PAR) storage in the KVM region.
You must install ESX, 3PAR or VSA before starting the HPE Helion OpenStack installation and are independent of HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade.
Ironic Baremetal Region
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade leverages the OpenStack Ironic service, which aims to provision bare metal machines instead of virtual machines. For more information, see Ironic Service Overview.
Unbonded or Bonded NIC configuration
The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation allows for network interface card bonding (bonded NIC).

section.p: HP Helion OpenStack offers many services based on the different OpenStack projects to provide the functionality you need. Visit the HPE Helion OpenStack Services Overview page for a complete list of services.
